meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's a great question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yael Kiselman-Lain
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'll chime in a little bit on this. There is also um so there's subsets of endocrine cells in the gut that are known to form sort of synapse like structures with sensory afference.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: And there's at least one publication that shows that uh luminal derived antigens, so they were using like fluorescent dextrins are taken up by those specific endocrine cells.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yael Kiselman-Lain
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay. And once such detection occurs assuming that it's a whole life bacteria that is that is being detected, can it then travel to the brain?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yael Kiselman-Lain
meeting_annotations.transcript: So to the CNS or it will die in the process.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um all right, so what's published is just antigen.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh my lab has some unpublished data showing that live bacteria can be taken up by those cells and that they can survive for at least 48 hours in a really small amount.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: But we haven't done any transfer experiments. So there's no there's no evidence to my knowledge of gut bacteria being viable and trafficking via these anatomical pathways to the brain.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I do think there's some experimental data at least from the oral or nasal microbiome showing that bacteria that are present at those epithelial surfaces uh can traffic across the the barrier and into the the brain and can actually be viable and live there. So it's not coming from the gut, um but it's another microbiome surface uh that that can directly at least shows as an example that that that bacteria can can do this.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yael Kiselman-Lain
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay. And and uh Michael, do you mentioned the TLRs are expressed on in the ENS? Are other innate receptors also expressed?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh yeah, so so first and for I was going to say um so the idea of a of a of a microbe, you know, traveling um through through a cell or living in a cell is, you know, we we know this in in viruses obviously, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: So that's kind of a cool thought that it is possible, but you know, no one's ever shown it. So I think that's also a really cool idea potentially um for for a grant idea. That's kind of far out there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: But anyways, um the other yeah, so I was actually talking about this yesterday uh with a couple people that if you because we've done this taking out different um um sensory neuron populations and done some some sequencing and we see um depending on the disease state or pathological state that your sensory neurons can look like, you know, neurons or they can have signatures that look like immune cells and have upregulation of of a wide variety of different receptors that are typically um uh immune in in nature. We call it like topic immune expression. And then there's some there's this is already out um that in a high fat diet or during obesity the the neurons look like fat cells um where they're um have more leptin and they respond to more more more like um um metabolic um signatures in the gut. So yeah, and the cool thing about these sensory neurons in the periphery is that they they can they can do this because they're, you know, they're outside of the blood brain barrier and they're able to be influenced by the by stimulus outside stimuli outside of the the brain.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: So.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laura Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: The TLRs are expressed on many types of cells in the brain too, neurons, gleal cells, microgleal cells and other astrocytes in the brain that also express many of the same cytokines that are expressed by immune cells. So I think you know, that's one of the interesting things. There's a great deal of blurring between the nervous system and the immune system in in many different compartments in the body.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laura Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: And that changes over time.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so if you do it if you do it in.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like if you look for toll, you you don't find it so much in the neurons in the brain, you find them in a lot of the glea.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um uh and maybe a couple neurons in a couple places.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um but you're right, there is definitely this a blur and the blur gets more real as you go more peripheral. Um hence why I think neuroinflammation, peripheral neuroinflammation is really interesting and and could be um an explanation for a lot of this cross talk.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: By directional communication between microbes um um peripheral immune stimulation and then uh neurodegenerative disease, PD, AD, what have you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michael Coleman-Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um so.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Very interesting.

meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I wanted to ask where kind of Michael's been talking about the peripheral neuroinflammation as one mechanism of triggering neurodegenerative disease.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wendy Bahr

meeting_annotations.transcript: So what would that when when it hits the brain?

meeting_annotations.transcript: What would that neuroinflammation process look like?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think that's a really cool question because I do think that's an outstanding gap in the field. We know for a lot of these age related neurodegenerative disorders that peripheral inflammation, intestinal inflammation can are are predisposing risk factors.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I don't think we know and if anybody else knows correct me, but I don't think we know how that inflammatory signal is potentiating those outcomes in the brain. meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeff Thompson
meeting_annotations.transcript: But then something that's more systemic, maybe it's it's actually just the cytokines that are passing through the blood or signaling through the blood brain barrier or cell invasion, immune cell invasion um that's triggered by those systemic inflammatory events.
